sections.title: Lending Basics
sections.content: Owner-occupied loans generally offer lower rates and down payments but require you to live in the property. Non-owner-occupied loans expect 20-25% down, higher reserves, and rent schedules. Lenders analyze property income and your personal debt-to-income ratio to gauge risk.

points.title: Conventional Loans
points.description: Best for 1-4 unit properties with strong borrowers; fixed rates and 30-year amortization keep payments predictable.

points.title: Debt-Service-Coverage Ratio (DSCR) Loans
points.description: Qualify primarily on the property's cash flow; ideal for investors with multiple mortgages or limited W-2 income.

points.title: Portfolio & Commercial Loans
points.description: Banks keep these loans on their books, offering flexibility for mixed-use or larger properties at higher rates.

sections.title: Mind the Reserves
sections.content: Most lenders want six months of mortgage payments in reserves for each financed property. Build this buffer into your acquisition plan.

sections.title: Creative Structures
sections.content: Seller financing, lease options, and partnerships can bridge gaps when bank financing falls short. Negotiate interest, amortization, and exit terms carefullyâ€”put everything in writing and consult legal counsel.

sections.title: Financing Prep Checklist
steps: Pull your credit report and address any derogatory marks before applying.
Compile two years of tax returns, recent pay stubs, and a personal financial statement.
Create a one-page summary of the target property including rent roll, expenses, and projected DSCR.
Contact three lenders (conventional, DSCR, portfolio) to compare terms and fees.
Model how rate changes impact cash flow so you know your break-even DSCR.

sections.title: Build Lender Relationships
sections.content: Even if you don't have a deal yet, introduce yourself to local lenders so they recognize you when the right property appears.
